title: Create steps in a flow
content:
When you create a step from an operation, decision, or flow, the step is an instance of that operation or flow and so inherits the inputs, outputs, and other characteristics.

Create a step from a flow, operation, or decision

  1. In the PROJECTS pane, double-click the flow in which you want to create the step, so that it opens in the authoring pane.

  2. Drag a flow/operation/decision to the authoring pane, from either the PROJECTS pane or the DEPENDENCIES pane. The step icon reflects whether the step was created from an operation, a flow, or a decision operation.

  3. To copy, cut, paste, and rename a step, select it and use appropriate buttons from the Authoring pane toolbar.

    You can also right-click the step and choose the following actions: Set as Start Step, Rename, Drill Down, Copy, Cut, Set as Loop, Set as Parallel Loop, and Delete.

    1. To copy a step, click the Copy button in the authoring pane toolbar or press Ctrl C keys, then click Paste button or press CTRL + V keys to paste.
    2. To cut a step, click the Cut button in the authoring pane toolbar or press Ctrl X keys, then click Paste button or press the CTRL + V keys to paste. You can copy and paste steps on the canvas multiple times as per your requirement.

    3. To rename a step, click the Edit button in the authoring pane toolbar. Enter a name for this step and click OK.

      For example, you may want to rename a step to reflect its function within the flow. you must note that a renamed step must not be a blank name and it should be unique in the flow. This applies to names with different case—for example, you cannot name one step to "Ping" and another to "ping".

  4. To delete a step from the canvas, select it and click the Delete button in the authoring pane toolbar. When you delete a step, any navigation lines linking this step to other steps are also deleted.

  5. To reorganize the steps and results on the canvas, click the auto-arrange icon from the authoring pane toolbar.

  6. To zoom-in or zoom-out of the canvas, you can use mouse-click and drag or scroll on the slider . To reset the zoom, click . The auto arrange, zoom and reset zoom icons are active and enabled in graph view only.

  7. Click Save .

Undo and redo actions in a flow

You can undo and redo an action in OO Workflow Designer for a flow that is triggered on an authoring pane. You can also view the entire list of actions in history and select any action from the list that is persisting in the memory to make further modifications and thereby overwrite the actions.

A maximum of 10 actions is stored in the memory. After the buffer of 10 actions in history is utilized, only the most recent actions will be retained including the initial state that will be always be kept in place.

Caution Each author’s history of states is stored individually and will be lost on closing the editor.

    You can also use Ctrl+Z and Ctrl+Y for undo and redo actions respectively.

  3. When you select a specific action from the history and skip existing actions.

    When you select a specific action from the history, the previously existing actions are displayed in grey. Any new action you make thereon will overwrite the grayed out actions.

  4. When future actions (grayed out actions as above) are overwritten by new actions.

View the step properties

  • Click a step in the authoring pane. The Step Properties pane appears on the right side of the canvas.

    The Properties pane contains the Input/Output tabs, with information about the selected step.

Drill down to view a subflow/operation within a step

To drill down within a step to see the details of the flow, decision, or operation that was used to create it:

  • Click the Drill Down into the Step button in the authoring pane toolbar.
